questions.title: Hydroelectric energy changes and power output

parts.text: A remote village uses a hydroelectric generator. The mass of water that passes through the generator each day is 2 500 000 kg. The change in vertical height of the water is 15.0 m. Gravitational field strength = 9.8 N/kg. Calculate the decrease in gravitational potential energy of the water.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $E_p = 2.5\times10^6 \times 9.8 \times 15.0$
1 mark: $E_p = 3.675\times10^8\,\text{J}$ (allow 3.7×10^8 J)

parts.text: Write down the equation which links energy (E), power (P) and time (t).
markScheme: Answer: A – $E = P t$

parts.text: Figure shows how the power output of the hydroelectric generator varied during one year. Explain one reason why the power output varied.
markScheme: 1 mark: The river flow / water level varies (e.g. rainfall varies).
1 mark: In drier periods (often summer) less water flows so power output is lower.

questions.title: UK electricity generation and daily demand

parts.text: The UK plans to stop using coal-fired power stations. Explain one environmental problem caused when electricity is generated by burning coal.
markScheme: 1 mark: Carbon dioxide (or other pollutants) released.
1 mark: Causes global warming / climate change (or acid rain/global dimming if explained).

parts.text: Give two renewable energy resources that could make up the ‘Other’ energy resources shown in Figure 1.
markScheme: 2 marks: Any two from wind, tidal, wave, hydroelectric, geothermal, biofuel/biomass.

parts.text: Using data from Figure 1, determine the percentage of electricity generated in nuclear power stations that day.
markScheme: 1 mark: Determine non-nuclear total shown (e.g. 78%).
1 mark: Nuclear percentage = **22%**.

parts.text: Figure 2 shows how the demand for electricity varied with time of day. What was the difference between the maximum demand and minimum demand during this day?
markScheme: 1 mark: Read maximum demand ≈ 37 500 MW and minimum ≈ 25 000 MW from the graph.
1 mark: Difference = **12 500 MW**.

parts.text: Demand increased between 06:00 and 09:00. Explain why solar power could have met the demand if enough solar panels were installed.
markScheme: 1 mark: Solar panels generate electricity from sunlight.
1 mark: Sunlight (and so power output) increases through the morning as the Sun rises.

questions.title: Dirty solar cells and economic impact

parts.text: A student covered a solar cell with increasing numbers of sheets of tracing paper. A decrease in the intensity of light reaching the solar cell causes ______ the output voltage from the solar cell.
markScheme: Answer: A — lower light intensity gives a lower output voltage.

parts.text: A homeowner pays £7600 for solar panels and expects to save £950 each year. Calculate the pay-back time.
markScheme: 1 mark: pay-back time = cost ÷ annual saving = 7600 ÷ 950
1 mark: pay-back time = **8 years**

parts.text: Allowing the surface of solar panels to become very dirty will ______ the pay-back time.
markScheme: Answer: C — dirt reduces output so pay-back takes longer.

parts.text: Explain your answer to the previous part.
markScheme: 1 mark: Dirty panels generate less electricity (lower power/voltage output).
1 mark: So savings/income from selling electricity are lower, increasing pay-back time.

questions.title: Reducing fossil fuels and power station response

parts.text: The wind is a renewable energy source. Name one more renewable energy source used to generate electricity.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any one from solar, hydroelectric, tidal, wave, biofuel/biomass, geothermal.

parts.text: Using less fossil fuels to generate electricity will ______ the amount of carbon dioxide emitted into the atmosphere.
markScheme: Answer: A — burning fewer fossil fuels releases less CO₂.

parts.text: Describe how the demand for electricity varied between 4.00 am and 10.00 am (use the graph).
markScheme: 1 mark: Demand increases from 4.00 am to about 8.00 am.
1 mark: Then demand remains approximately constant from about 8.00 am to 10.00 am.

parts.text: Which type of power station has the fastest start-up time?
markScheme: Answer: B — natural gas power stations can start up quickly.

parts.text: Classify each energy resource as renewable or non-renewable. Choose from the box for each blank.
markScheme: 1 mark: At least 3 correct: biofuel (renewable), coal (non-renewable), nuclear (non-renewable), tides (renewable).
1 mark: All 4 correct.

parts.text: Transformers are used to make power transmission efficient. Complete the sentences using words from the box.
segments: transfer from the overhead transmission cables to the surroundings.
markScheme: 1 mark: **potential difference**
1 mark: **current**
1 mark: **energy**
1 mark: **potential difference**

parts.text: Write down the equation which links charge flow (Q), current (I) and time (t).
markScheme: Answer: A – $Q = I t$

parts.text: The solar cells on the roof of a house always face in the same direction. Explain one disadvantage caused by the solar cells only facing in one direction.
markScheme: 1 mark: Solar cells are not always pointed directly at the Sun / do not track the Sun.
1 mark: So they do not always receive maximum light intensity / generate maximum electricity.

parts.text: The mean current from the solar cells to the battery is 3.5 A. Calculate the charge flow in 3600 s.
markScheme: 1 mark: Substitution: $Q = 3.5 \times 3600$

parts.text: Write down the equation which links efficiency, total power input and useful power output.
markScheme: Answer: A – $\text{efficiency} = \frac{\text{useful power output}}{\text{total power input}}$

parts.text: At one time, the total power input to the solar cells was 7500 W and the efficiency was 0.16. Calculate the useful power output.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: useful power = 0.16 × 7500
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: useful power = efficiency × total power input
1 mark: Final answer: **1200 W**

parts.text: Energy that is dissipated is less useful. What happens to energy that has been dissipated?
options: The energy is used to generate electricity.
markScheme: Answer: A — dissipated energy is spread out and becomes less useful.

parts.text: Why is it unlikely that all the UK’s electricity needs could be met by solar power systems?
options: A very large area would need to be covered with solar cells.
Solar power is a non-renewable energy resource.
The efficiency of solar cells is too high.
markScheme: Answer: A — the required area would be very large.

questions.title: Solar thermal station components and stored energy

parts.text: Complete the sentences about a solar thermal power station.
segments: by the mirrors towards the solar receiver.
At the solar receiver, water is heated in a
which turns the water into steam.
which is connected to a generator.
is used to change the voltage for transmission along power lines.
markScheme: 1 mark: **reflected**
1 mark: **boiler**
1 mark: **turbine**
1 mark: **transformer**

parts.text: A solar storage power station can supply a maximum electrical power of 140 000 kW for 15 hours. Calculate the maximum energy stored, in kWh.
markScheme: 1 mark: Substitution: $E = 140\,000 \times 15$

parts.text: Write down the equation which links density (ρ), mass (m) and volume (V).
markScheme: Answer: A – $\rho = \frac{m}{V}$

parts.text: Write down the equation which links energy transferred (E), power (P) and time (t).
markScheme: Answer: A – $E = P t$

parts.text: The graph shows UK demand for electricity over one day. The hydroelectric power station can provide 1.5 × 10^9 W for a maximum of 5 hours. Give two reasons why this power station cannot meet the increase in demand between 04:00 and 16:00.
markScheme: 1 mark: The increase/variation in demand is greater than the station’s maximum power output.
1 mark: Demand remains high for longer than 5 hours (04:00 to 16:00 is 12 hours).

questions.title: Energy transfers, efficiency and the National Grid

parts.text: Complete the energy transformation diagram by filling in the missing energy store.
segments: Gravitational potential energy of the falling water →
energy of the Archimedean screw → Electrical energy generated
markScheme: 1 mark: **kinetic**

parts.text: Each second, the micro-hydroelectricity generator transforms 80 000 J of gravitational potential energy into 60 000 J of electrical energy. Calculate the efficiency.
markScheme: 1 mark: Substitution: efficiency = 60 000 / 80 000
1 mark: efficiency = **0.75** (or 75%)

parts.text: What is the National Grid?
markScheme: 1 mark: A system/network of **cables and transformers** that distributes electricity.

parts.text: Explain why transferring electricity directly to local homes is more efficient than using the National Grid to distribute electricity.
markScheme: 1 mark: Less energy is wasted/ lost as heat in the cables.
1 mark: Because the cables are shorter (so lower resistance/less heating).
